meta.title: Platformer
meta.description: Platformer game with movement abilities, levels, enemies, and power-ups.

decks.name: Movement Abilities
decks.description: Individual movement mechanics and abilities. Add a new movement type as a card, then start its journey to create implementation tasks.

steps.content:
Implement Mechanic Logic

Code the core functionality of this movement ability.

- [ ] Design implementation approach
- [ ] Write core logic
- [ ] Add edge case handling
- [ ] Write unit tests
- [ ] Code review

Create Animations

Animate the player performing this movement.

- [ ] Plan animation keyframes
- [ ] Block out motion
- [ ] Refine timing and curves
- [ ] Add secondary motion
- [ ] Test in game context

Tune Feel & Responsiveness

Playtest and adjust timing, speed, and feel until it's satisfying.

- [ ] Define success criteria
- [ ] Implement initial values
- [ ] Playtest
- [ ] Iterate based on feedback
- [ ] Document final values

Add Audio Feedback

Create sound effects for the movement.

- [ ] Record or source base sounds
- [ ] Edit and layer audio
- [ ] Add variations
- [ ] Integrate in engine
- [ ] Test in game context

cards.content:
Double Jump

A second jump the player can perform while in mid-air. Decide if this is available from the start or unlocked later as a progression reward.

**Unlocked by:** Double Jump Boots

This card has the **#tier-2** tag, meaning it's mid-game content. Tags help you filter and organize cards - define your own tag system that fits your project!

Wall Slide

Player slows their fall when touching a wall. Often paired with wall-jump. Consider: Does it drain stamina? How much does it slow the fall?

> **Effort:** This card could be estimated at 5 effort points. Use effort to estimate how much work a feature will take - helpful for planning sprints!

Dash

A quick horizontal burst of speed. Consider: Can it be used in mid-air? Does it have a cooldown? Can it pass through enemies?

**Unlocked by:** Speed Boots

Dash is great for speedrunning and adds skill expression to movement.

Basic Jump

The player's standard jump ability. Define the jump height and whether it's fixed or variable based on button hold duration.

> **About Sub-Cards:** Notice the sub-cards attached below? These were created automatically by starting this card's journey. Each sub-card represents a production task (coding, animation, audio, etc.) needed to bring this mechanic to life.

> **Priority:** This card is marked as priority 'a' - the highest priority. Use priority to signal what's most important to work on first.

decks.name: Levels
decks.description: All game levels. Add a level card, then start its journey to create production tasks.

steps.content:
Create Level Layout & Blockout

Design the level flow, challenge progression, and placement of enemies/collectibles.

Create Level Art Assets

Build environment art, props, and visual themes for this level.

Implement Level Mechanics & Scripting

Code level-specific mechanics, triggers, and events.

- [ ] Design implementation approach
- [ ] Write core logic
- [ ] Add edge case handling
- [ ] Write unit tests
- [ ] Code review

Design Level Music & Ambiance

Create the music track and ambient sounds for this level.

- [ ] Record or source base sounds
- [ ] Edit and layer audio
- [ ] Add variations
- [ ] Integrate in engine
- [ ] Test in game context

Playtest & Balance Level Difficulty

Test the level and adjust difficulty, pacing, and challenge.

- [ ] Define success criteria
- [ ] Implement initial values
- [ ] Playtest
- [ ] Iterate based on feedback
- [ ] Document final values

cards.content:
Tutorial Level

The first level where players learn the basic controls. Introduce one mechanic at a time in a safe environment. Consider: What's the minimum they need to know to start playing?

**Teaches:** Basic Jump

Level 1: Grasslands

The first real level after the tutorial. Build on what was taught and add light challenge. This sets the tone for your game's difficulty curve.

Level 2: Crystal Caves

Introduce a new mechanic or enemy type here. Consider: What's the next challenge after players master Level 1?

decks.name: Enemies
decks.description: Enemy types and behaviors. Add an enemy, start its journey to create production tasks.

steps.content:
Create Enemy Concept Art

Draw concept art exploring the enemy's visual design.

Create Enemy Sprite/Model & Animations

Build the enemy's model and animate its behaviors (idle, attack, death, etc.).

- [ ] Block out basic shapes
- [ ] Refine high-poly details
- [ ] Create low-poly version
- [ ] UV unwrap
- [ ] Texture and materials
- [ ] Test in engine

Implement Enemy AI & Behavior

Code the enemy's movement patterns, attack logic, and reactions.

- [ ] Design implementation approach
- [ ] Write core logic
- [ ] Add edge case handling
- [ ] Write unit tests
- [ ] Code review

Design Enemy SFX

Create sound effects for movement, attacks, and death.

- [ ] Record or source base sounds
- [ ] Edit and layer audio
- [ ] Add variations
- [ ] Integrate in engine
- [ ] Test in game context

Balance Enemy Stats & Placement

Tune health, damage, speed, and decide where this enemy appears in levels.

- [ ] Define success criteria
- [ ] Implement initial values
- [ ] Playtest
- [ ] Iterate based on feedback
- [ ] Document final values

cards.content:
Flying Bat

An aerial enemy that requires different tactics than ground enemies. Consider: Does it patrol or chase? How fast? Can players jump on it?

Spike Trap

A stationary hazard that teaches players to watch where they land. Consider: Always active or periodic? How much damage? Can it be destroyed?

**First appears in:** Level 1: Grasslands

Create Enemy Concept Art

Draw concept art exploring the enemy's visual design.

Create Enemy Sprite/Model & Animations

Build the enemy's model and animate its behaviors (idle, attack, death, etc.).

- [ ] Block out basic shapes
- [ ] Refine high-poly details
- [ ] Create low-poly version
- [ ] UV unwrap
- [ ] Texture and materials
- [ ] Test in engine

Implement Enemy AI & Behavior

Code the enemy's movement patterns, attack logic, and reactions.

- [ ] Design implementation approach
- [ ] Write core logic
- [ ] Add edge case handling
- [ ] Write unit tests
- [ ] Code review

Design Enemy SFX

Create sound effects for movement, attacks, and death.

- [ ] Record or source base sounds
- [ ] Edit and layer audio
- [ ] Add variations
- [ ] Integrate in engine
- [ ] Test in game context

Balance Enemy Stats & Placement

Tune health, damage, speed, and decide where this enemy appears in levels.

- [ ] Define success criteria
- [ ] Implement initial values
- [ ] Playtest
- [ ] Iterate based on feedback
- [ ] Document final values

Slime

Your basic enemy type. Simple, predictable behavior that teaches players the combat basics. Consider: How does the player defeat it? Jump on it? Attack button?

**First appears in:** Level 1: Grasslands

decks.name: Power-ups
decks.description: Collectibles and abilities. Add a power-up, start its journey to create production tasks.

steps.content:
Create Power-up Icon/Model

Design the visual representation of this power-up.

- [ ] Block out basic shapes
- [ ] Refine high-poly details
- [ ] Create low-poly version
- [ ] UV unwrap
- [ ] Texture and materials
- [ ] Test in engine

Implement Power-up Logic

Code what happens when the player collects this power-up.

- [ ] Design implementation approach
- [ ] Write core logic
- [ ] Add edge case handling
- [ ] Write unit tests
- [ ] Code review

Design Power-up SFX & VFX

Create the collection sound and any visual effects.

- [ ] Record or source base sounds
- [ ] Edit and layer audio
- [ ] Add variations
- [ ] Integrate in engine
- [ ] Test in game context

Balance Power-up Effect & Duration

Tune how powerful the effect is and how long it lasts (for temporary power-ups).

- [ ] Define success criteria
- [ ] Implement initial values
- [ ] Playtest
- [ ] Iterate based on feedback
- [ ] Document final values

cards.content:
Health Potion

A consumable that restores player health. Decide: How much does it heal? Is it instant or over time? Does it drop from enemies or sit in the world?

Double Jump Boots

A permanent upgrade that unlocks the double jump ability.

**Unlocks:** Double Jump
**Found in:** Level 2: Crystal Caves

This shows how power-ups can gate progression - players return to earlier levels with new abilities to reach previously inaccessible areas.

decks.name: Design Notes
decks.description: Design documentation, meeting notes, and playtesting findings. Use this deck to capture design decisions and their rationale.

cards.content:
Design Meeting: Jump Feel

**Date:** Sprint 1
**Attendees:** Lead Designer, Programmer

**Key Decisions:**
- Variable jump height based on button hold
- Slight 'coyote time' (can jump shortly after leaving platform)
- Reduced gravity on jump apex for 'floaty' feel

**Rationale:** We want jumping to feel responsive and forgiving while still requiring skill for precise platforming.

**Related to:** Basic Jump card

Playtesting Notes: Tutorial Level

**Session:** Week 3 playtest
**Findings:**
- 80% of players understood jump without instruction
- 30% didn't realize they could control jump height
- First enemy encounter too early

**Changes Made:** Added floating text hint for variable jump, moved first slime encounter later.
